Award.AbstractNarration:
Robotics and autonomous systems (RAS) technology has utility to diverse industries, including robotics, mineral extraction, shipping and transport, manufacturing, construction, agriculture, and defense which, together, created 27% of US GDP in 2014. The development of RAS instrumentation that serves manufacturing industries is estimated to increase productivity up to 22%. Distance sensing instrumentation is critically important for RAS as it allows these systems to map their surrounding environments, safely perform tasks, and intelligently react to changes in the environment. The objective of this proposal is to translate a resonant light detection and ranging (R-LIDAR) instrument that enables high-performance, small-size, and low-cost distance sensing through the use of a resonant optomechanical scanner from the laboratory to the marketplace. This instrument senses distance over a large field-of-view with high resolution and frame rates using a small size, weight, and power (SWAP) system.

The R-LIDAR system can be expected to make a significant commercial impact in an addressable LIDAR distance sensor market, a market expected to reach $625 million/year by 2020. Development of high-performance resonant optomechanical scanners for R-LIDAR systems would also benefit related disciplines that use beam scanning technologies such as microscopy, endoscopy, light machining, and display. NSF Innovation Corps Teams Program (I-Corps Teams) resources will provide insight through customer interviews of the viability of the R-LIDAR technology in the marketplace, information regarding desired instrument design attributes, funds for technology development, and a transition plan for commercializing the technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We participated in the NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) cohort at the University of Michigan in Fall 2015. Team members included Christopher Brown (PI), Darryl Ngai (Entrepreneurial Lead -- EL), and Karl Ginter (Industry Mentor). Our goal was to assess the product market fit of a novel light detection and ranging (LIDAR) distance sensing technology. The novel technology has attributes that include low-cost, high-performance, and small size, weight, and power (SWAP) consumption. Prior to starting the I-Corps program the team hypothesized that the technology attributes would be attractive to customers developing autonomous vehicles for the automotive market.

The I-Corps program helped the team identify the value propositions of the technology for potential customers. PI and EL team members were also exposed to business concepts and developed entrepreneurial capabilities. Conducting 100 interviews during the Fall 2015 cohort, the team discovered risks to commercializing the sensor technology for the autonomous vehicle automotive market that include: (1) uncertainty regarding the timing of autonomous vehicle market coalescence, (2) uncertainty relating to autonomous vehicle sensor and control system requirements subject to ongoing research and development, and (3) business risk relating to the automotive customer requirement for large-volume, low-cost sensor production. Customer exploration activities continued following participation in the Fall 2015 cohort, allowing for identification of a near-term business opportunity for the novel distance sensing technology to provide high-accuracy distance measurements useful for the small unmanned aircraft system (sUAS) commercial surveying market. In this market the SWAP attributes of the novel distance sensing technology are valued by sUAS integrators. Survey service providers value high-accuracy data acquired using LIDAR technology and the operational efficiencies enabled by sUAS surveying. End users value the low-cost, high-accuracy distance data as it allows for improved decision making in the construction, mining, and environmental sensing industries.

The team has moved forward with commercializing the distance sensing technology and has achieved significant milestones since participating in the I-Corps program, including: (1) founding a company, Z-senz LLC, to commercialize the distance sensing technology, (2) acquiring grant funding to support R&D and commercialization efforts, and (3) achieving burgeoning partnerships and sales to sUAS integrators. Team members are thankful to the NSF for the opportunity to participate in the I-Corps program as the program enabled these significant commercial milestones.
